item.title: Coronavirus Global News Tracker: Latest Updates
item.description: Some lessons: We will live with the virus for a long time and you should be wearing a mask. Paris is reopening cafe terraces.
item.media:credit: Stephen Speranza for The New York Times
item.media:description: A funeral home in Queens in April. The coronavirus has killed more than 29,000 people in New York.

item.title: ​‘Tell Me Who My Mother Is’: A Korean Adoptee Seeks Her Roots
item.description: Armed with DNA test results, Kara Bos is asking a South Korean court to rule that an 85-year-old man in Seoul is her father. Her paternity lawsuit could set a precedent for overseas adoptees.
item.dc:creator: Choe Sang-Hun

item.title: In Egypt, Images From American Protests Evoke a Lost Revolution
item.description: Memories of 2011’s Arab Spring, and its fragile hopes, have been revived in the minds of many Egyptians as they’ve watched a strikingly similar dynamic play out in the United States.
item.dc:creator: Declan Walsh
item.category: Middle East and North Africa Unrest (2010- )
item.media:credit: Ed Ou for The New York Times

item.title: At Drive-in Disco, It ‘Feels like Saturday Again,’ Even Without a Dance Floor
item.description: To stop the spread of the coronavirus, nightclubs are still shuttered as Europe emerges from a lockdown. But one German club has found another way to host a party. Honk if you’re having a good time.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Laetitia Vancon
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: After German nightlife shut down in March, a club in Schüttorf, a small town in north-western Germany, pioneered the concept of a drive-in disco.

item.title: Abused Woman Who Killed Husband Is Granted the Family’s U.K. Estate
item.description: Sally Challen’s landmark case has put a spotlight on the fight against domestic abuse in Britain.
item.dc:creator: Elian Peltier
item.media:credit: Yui Mok/Press Association, via Associated Press
item.media:description: Sally Challen with her son David after her conviction was quashed last June.

item.title: Hong Kong Bans Tiananmen Vigil for 1st Time, in New Challenge to Protests
item.description: Days after China moved to enact new security laws for Hong Kong, the territory’s police rejected permission for an annual vigil to honor the victims of the 1989 Tiananmen Square protests.
item.dc:creator: Austin Ramzy
item.category: Hong Kong Alliance in Support of Patriotic Democratic Movements of China
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: Hong Kong had held a vigil every year on the anniversary of the Tiananmen Square crackdown. Thousands gathered for it in 2019.

item.title: Trump and Putin Discuss Russia’s Attendance at G7, but Allies Are Wary
item.description: The British and Canadian governments oppose admitting Russia into the bloc, as President Trump continues a renewed courtship of Russia’s leader.
item.dc:creator: Michael Crowley
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump meeting with President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia during the G20 summit in Osaka, Japan, last year.

item.title: China Responds with Restraint to Trump's Move to End Hong Kong's 'Special Status'
item.description: A foreign ministry spokesman stayed close to the Communist Party’s official position on Hong Kong, suggesting that Beijing was waiting to see the specifics of the U.S. plan.
item.dc:creator: Amy Qin
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: A screen in Hong Kong last month showed a broadcast about Beijing’s proposed national security legislation for the territory.

item.title: New Ebola Outbreak in Congo, Already Hit by Measles and Coronavirus
item.description: Five people have died in Mbandaka, a western city more than 750 miles away from another Ebola outbreak in the country. It is unclear how the disease emerged in the city during lockdown.
item.dc:creator: Ruth Maclean
item.media:credit: Finbarr O'Reilly for The New York Times
item.media:description: An ebola treatment center in Mangima, a town outside of Beni in eastern Democratic Republic of the Congo, last year. Experts are trying to understand how the disease has now emerged in the west while the country is under travel restrictions because of the coronavirus.

item.title: As Protests Engulf the United States, China Revels in the Unrest
item.description: Chinese officials and state media are seizing on the moment to tout Beijing’s authoritarian system and condemn American hypocrisy — a narrative that ignores many of their own issues.
item.dc:creator: Javier C. Hernández
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters being detained by the police in Minneapolis on Sunday.

item.title: Live Stock Market Tracker and Updates
item.description: The latest on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.
item.media:credit: Lynne Sladky/Associated Press
item.media:description: Rosemary Arends, right, a nurse and flight attendant for South African Airways, checking the temperature of a passenger before a charter flight from Miami International Airport.

item.title: Voices From the Protests
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Jonathan Ernst/Reuters
item.media:description: Demonstrations near the White House in Washington on Sunday.

item.title: The Flynn Calls: His Dismissal of Russian Interference and the Kremlin’s Savvy
item.description: Newly declassified transcripts show the seeds of Russia’s overtures to the Trump administration as both sides sought to downplay Moscow’s election sabotage.
item.dc:creator: Mark Mazzetti
item.category: Russian Interference in 2016 US Elections and Ties to Trump Associates
item.media:credit: Tom Brenner for The New York Times
item.media:description: In the calls, Michael T. Flynn referred to Russia’s election interference effort only as “the cyberstuff.”

item.title: Where the Virus Is Growing Most: Countries With ‘Illiberal Populist’ Leaders
item.description: Brazil, Russia, Britain and the U.S. have something in common.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt and Lauren Leatherby
item.media:credit: Evaristo Sa/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: President Jair Bolsonaro of Brazil greeted supporters in Brasilia on Sunday.

item.title: His Family Fled Syria. He Didn’t Cry Until He Heard About His Sisters.
item.description: Yousef was just 13 when his family left Syria for Europe. Five years later, he’s adjusting to life separated from his three sisters and the ups and downs of adolescence.
item.dc:creator: Alia Malek
item.category: Middle East and Africa Migrant Crisis

item.title: George Floyd, Donald Trump, Hong Kong: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: Sean Gallup/Getty Images

item.title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
item.description: Public health experts are concerned that mass demonstrations could seed a possible second wave of infections.
item.dc:creator: Jonathan Wolfe
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: Minneapolis, Tiananmen Vigil, Israel: Your Tuesday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Melina Delkic and Carole Landry
item.media:credit: Piet Van Der Meer/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: A demonstration in Amsterdam on Monday against racism and police brutality.

item.title: After Reality Star’s Death, Japan Vows to Rip the Mask Off Online Hate
item.description: While many in the country abhor the kind of harassment Hana Kimura endured before her apparent suicide, some warn that cracking down on it could also chill rising internet activism.
item.dc:creator: Ben Dooley and Hikari Hida
item.media:credit: Etsuo Hara/Getty Images
item.media:description: Hana Kimura in Tokyo in 2019. She apparently committed suicide after facing relentless criticism online.

item.title: Mass Extinctions Are Accelerating, Scientists Report
item.description: Five hundred species are likely to become extinct over the next two decades, according to a new study.
item.dc:creator: Rachel Nuwer
item.category: International Union for Conservation of Nature
Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences
item.media:credit: Carl De Souza/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A farmer walked through a burned area of Amazon rainforest near Porto Velho, Brazil, last year.

item.title: Putin Sets New Date for Vote on Extending His Rule
item.description: His political program and ratings derailed by the coronavirus, President Vladimir Putin of Russia is pushing to get back on track.
item.dc:creator: Andrew Higgins
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Alexei Nikolsky
item.media:description: President Vladimir V. Putin of Russia at his Novo-Ogaryovo residence outside Moscow, on Monday.

item.title: Netanyahu’s Annexation Plans Meet Surprise Opponent: Israeli Settlers
item.description: Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu has promised to annex much of the occupied West Bank. But now that he can, there are questions about whether he will.
item.dc:creator: David M. Halbfinger and Adam Rasgon
item.media:credit: Dan Balilty for The New York Times
item.media:description: The Israeli settlement of Ariel in the West Bank. Prime Minister Benjamin Netanyahu is suddenly facing resistance to annexation from settler leaders who have been agitating for it for years.

item.title: How India’s Police Used a Pandemic to Boost Its Image
item.description: The police in New Delhi were roundly vilified for their role in religious violence. Now they’re on the front line of the city’s fight against coronavirus. Our reporters rode along as officers transported sick patients and served meals.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman, Karan Deep Singh, Caroline Kim and Hari Kumar
item.media:credit: Karan Deep Singh/The New York Times
item.media:description: Karan Deep Singh/The New York Times

item.title: ‘The Minnesota Paradox’
item.description: And what else you need to know today.
item.dc:creator: David Leonhardt
item.media:credit: Victor J. Blue for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters in front of the 5th Precinct in Minneapolis on Saturday.

item.title: Tear Gas Clears Path for Trump to Visit Church
item.description: Police officers used flash grenades to disperse a crowd so the president could visit for a photo opportunity. And in New York, protesters and looters defied a curfew.
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters outside the White House, where President Trump called violent demonstrations in American cities “domestic terrorism.”

item.title: Finding Euphoria in Bangkok’s Food Scene
item.description: In search of creative inspiration, a New York-based photographer spent two weeks documenting Bangkok’s fresh markets and street vendors.
item.dc:creator: Louise Palmberg

item.title: As Coronavirus Toll Preoccupies U.S., Rivals Test Limits of American Power
item.description: The coronavirus may have changed almost everything, but it didn’t change this: Global competition spins ahead — and in many ways has accelerated.
item.dc:creator: David E. Sanger, Eric Schmitt and Edward Wong
item.media:credit: Australia Department Of Defence, via Reuters
item.media:description: The amphibious assault ship America conducted maneuvers with other Australian and U.S. Navy vessels in the South China Sea in April, one of four such operations this year.

item.title: U.S. Economy Faces Long-Term Recovery, C.B.O. Says
item.description: The latest on stock market and business news during the coronavirus outbreak.

item.title: The Best Movies and TV Shows New to Netflix, Amazon and Stan in Australia in June
item.description: Our picks for June, including ‘Queer Eye,’ ‘Da 5 Bloods,’ ‘Scarface’ and ‘LOL: Last One Laughing Australia’
item.dc:creator: Noel Murray

item.title: Global Anger Grows Over George Floyd Death, and Becomes an Anti-Trump Cudgel
item.description: Public outcries over racism in the United States erupted from Addis Ababa to Vancouver. China and Iran, criticized on human rights by the Trump administration, called the killing of Mr. Floyd a symbol of American hypocrisy.
item.dc:creator: Javier C. Hernández and Benjamin Mueller
item.media:credit: Sean Gallup/Getty Images
item.media:description: Demonstrators marched in Berlin on Sunday to protest the death of George Floyd at the hands of police in Minneapolis.

item.title: U.S. Protests, Coronavirus, SpaceX: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Isabella Kwai
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters in Los Angeles on Saturday.

item.title: Pandemic to Cost U.S. Economy $7.9 Trillion Over 10 Years
item.description: Michigan’s governor lifted a stay-at-home order as other states announced steps to reopen. A Rohingya Muslim who lived in a Bangladesh refugee camp died of the coronavirus.
item.media:credit: Chang W. Lee/The New York Times
item.media:description: Protests in Manhattan on Sunday.

item.title: Your Monday Briefing
item.description: U.S. protests, Hong Kong, SpaceX: Here’s what you need to know.
item.dc:creator: Carole Landry
item.media:credit: Bryan Denton for The New York Times
item.media:description: Protesters in Los Angeles on Saturday.

item.title: Resisting Lockdown, Nicaragua Becomes a Place of Midnight Burials
item.description: The country is one of the last to reject the strict measures introduced globally to curb the spread of the coronavirus. Families say they are paying the price.
item.dc:creator: Alfonso Flores Bermúdez and Frances Robles
item.media:credit: Inti Ocon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Across Nicaragua, families are being forced to hold rushed funerals at all hours of the night, without time to call a priest or buy flowers.

item.title: Rogue Trip by Boris Johnson Aide Makes U.K.’s Spectator Part of the Story
item.description: A senior editor of the magazine, Britain’s oldest, did not disclose in an article that her husband, Dominic Cummings, had taken a 260-mile trip that breached the nation’s stay-at-home order.
item.dc:creator: Mark Landler and Stephen Castle
item.media:credit: Jim Watson/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Boris Johnson in 2003, reading an issue of The Spectator marking 175 years of publication, when he was the magazine’s editor.

item.title: Coronavirus Turns a Spanish Sea Delicacy Back Into Daily Fare
item.description: With high-end restaurants closed, the price of prawns has tumbled, allowing fishmongers to pick up the shellfish at a discount and offer them to a much broader clientele.
item.dc:creator: Raphael Minder
item.media:credit: Samuel Aranda for The New York Times
item.media:description: Unloading the catch of the day in Llançà, Spain, in early May. When fishing for prawns, 12 hours at sea can yield barely a dozen kilograms.

item.title: Mexico’s President Says Most Domestic Violence Calls Are ‘Fake’
item.description: The leader compared the requests for help to prank calls, the latest controversy over his government’s response to record levels of violence against women.
item.dc:creator: Natalie Kitroeff
item.category: Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Mexico's Presidency, via Reuters
item.media:description: President Andrés Manuel López Obrador of Mexico’s messaging when addressing record-high levels of violence against women has been called dismissive or condescending by critics.

item.title: Western Countries Leave Children of ISIS in Syrian Camps
item.description: The children are living in squalid detention camps lacking schools, health care and clean water, and where disease and jihadist ideology are rampant.
item.dc:creator: Ben Hubbard and Constant Méheut
item.category: Islamic State in Iraq and Syria (ISIS)
Human Rights and Human Rights Violations
item.media:credit: Ivor Prickett for The New York Times
item.media:description: Women and children who fled ISIS-controlled territory in southern Syria at Al Hol camp last year.

item.title: U.S. Sends Two Million Doses of Hydroxychloroquine to Brazil
item.description: The two countries are studying whether the drug is safe and effective for the prevention and early treatment of Covid-19. Nicaragua has become a place of midnight burials.
item.media:credit: Antonio Lacerda/EPA, via Shutterstock
item.media:description: Workers bury a victim of the coronavirus at a cemetery in Rio de Janeiro on Friday.

item.title: China and India Brawl at 14,000 Feet Along the Border
item.description: As China projects its power across Asia, and along the disputed India-China border in the Himalayas, India is feeling surrounded. Both sides insist they don’t want a war, but thousands of troops have been sent.
item.dc:creator: Jeffrey Gettleman and Steven Lee Myers
item.media:credit: Paula Bronstein/Getty Images
item.media:description: An Indian military officer on patrol in Ladakh, India, in August.

item.title: Rabbis to Return to German Military Amid Growing Anti-Semitism
item.description: The Army will welcome rabbis into its chaplaincy this year to provide spiritual support to Jewish soldiers as anti-Semitism surges in the country.
item.dc:creator: Melissa Eddy
item.media:credit: Fabrizio Bensch/Reuters
item.media:description: Army recruits in Viereck, Germany, in 2018. An estimated 300 Jewish soldiers serve the country in missions abroad.

item.title: In Some Nations, Coronavirus Is Only One of Many Outbreaks
item.description: In countries like Honduras, the virus has diverted resources from efforts to fight other serious diseases, straining weak public health systems, draining supplies and unraveling hard-won gains.
item.dc:creator: Kirk Semple
item.media:credit: Daniele Volpe for The New York Times
item.media:description: A ward for children with dengue at Mario Catarino Rivas Hospital in San Pedro Sula, Honduras, in December.

item.title: Coronavirus Slams Broken, Embattled Yemen
item.description: Lacking equipment, expertise and authority, a divided, war-torn country bobbles a response to a surging pandemic.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Yee
item.media:credit: Khaled Abdullah/Reuters
item.media:description: Security personnel in protective clothing in Sana, the Houthi-controlled capital of Yemen.

item.title: Twitter Had Been Drawing a Line for Months When Trump Crossed It
item.description: Inside the company, one faction wanted Jack Dorsey, Twitter’s chief, to take a hard line against the president’s tweets while another urged him to remain hands-off.
item.dc:creator: Kate Conger
item.media:credit: Toby Melville/Reuters
item.media:description: Jack Dorsey, Twitter’s chief executive, has recently delegated policy decisions, watching internal debate from the sidelines.

item.title: In Hong Kong, Anxiety and Defiance Over Trump’s Move to Cut Ties
item.description: The reactions to President Trump’s decision fell along familiar political fault lines in a city wracked by nearly a year of protests.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang and Amy Qin
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: News broadcasts in Hong Kong this week about China’s plan to impose national security legislation.

item.title: Live Coronavirus Pandemic Updates: G7, Lake of the Ozarks, W.H.O., India, California
item.description: The German chancellor had announced earlier Saturday that she would not travel to the U.S. for the G7. Businesses are starting up again, but workers commuting by public transportation face dilemmas.
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Henning Schacht
item.media:description: Chancellor Angela Merkel of Germany in Berlin on Wednesday.

item.title: Hong Kong's Protest Movement, Faced with Beijing's Security Push, is In Crisis
item.description: As the Chinese government’s grip tightens, protesters are debating how and why to keep fighting, or whether resistance is even possible.
item.dc:creator: Vivian Wang, Tiffany May, Austin Ramzy and Lam Yik Fei
item.media:credit: Lam Yik Fei for The New York Times
item.media:description: A protester against new security laws at Causeway Bay, Hong Kong, on Sunday.

item.title: Coronavirus Briefing: What Happened Today
item.description: The C.D.C. recommended big changes to the way office spaces are laid out.
item.dc:creator: Lara Takenaga and Jonathan Wolfe
item.media:credit: The New York Times

item.title: A Continent Reopens
item.description: Patrick Kingsley, an international correspondent, and Laetitia Vancon, a photojournalist, are driving 3,700 miles to explore the reopening of the European continent after coronavirus lockdowns.
item.dc:creator: Patrick Kingsley and Laetitia Vancon
item.media:credit: Laetitia Vancon for The New York Times
item.media:description: Life is slowly returning to normal in Berlin.

item.title: When Going to Work Means Taking a Calculated Risk
item.description: The coronavirus hasn’t gone away. But an increasing number of Canadians are heading back to workplaces that may increase their risk of infection.
item.dc:creator: Ian Austen
item.media:credit: Sebastien St-Jean/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: An employee, left, at the Simons department store in downtown Montreal explaining safety procedures to a customer.

item.title: Blaming China for Pandemic, Trump Says U.S. Will Leave the W.H.O.
item.description: America’s decades-long relationship with the organization has been instrumental in improving health around the world.
item.dc:creator: Donald G. McNeil Jr. and Andrew Jacobs
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Erin Schaff/The New York Times
item.media:description: President Trump made the announcement Friday in the Rose Garden.

item.title: In Brazil, Bolsonaro Lashes Out at Investigators
item.description: President Jair Bolsonaro and his allies have taken an increasingly belligerent stance toward the array of criminal and legislative investigations engulfing his office.
item.dc:creator: Manuela Andreoni, Letícia Casado and Kirk Semple
item.media:credit: Adriano Machado/Reuters
item.media:description: President Jair Bolsonaro of Brazil. The fast-spreading coronavirus has sent the economy into a tailspin and caused the deaths of more than 27,000 people.

item.title: It’s Not Whether You Were Exposed to the Coronavirus. It’s How Much.
item.description: The pathogen is proving a familiar adage: The dose makes the poison.
item.dc:creator: Apoorva Mandavilli
item.category: Centers for Disease Control and Prevention
item.media:credit: Misha Friedman for The New York Times
item.media:description: Harry Henri, a research assistant, working with blood samples from coronavirus patients at SUNY Downstate’s BioBank in Brooklyn.

item.title: Taiwan Court Strikes Down Law Criminalizing Adultery
item.description: The decision was hailed by rights activists who said the law had disproportionately targeted women.
item.dc:creator: Amy Qin
item.media:credit: Sam Yeh/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: Chief Justice Hsu Tzong-li, center, in 2017. He called the law a “serious invasion of personal privacy.”

item.title: Economic Giants Are Restarting. Here’s What It Means for Climate Change.
item.description: Want to know whether the world can avert catastrophe? Watch the recovery plans coming out now in Europe, China and the United States.
item.dc:creator: Somini Sengupta
item.media:credit: Kola Sulaimon/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A demonstrator in Abuja, Nigeria, on a day of global climate strikes in September.

item.title: Congress Calls State Dept. Officials for Interviews in Expanded Pompeo Inquiry
item.description: Lawmakers are investigating whether Secretary of State Mike Pompeo urged President Trump to fire Steve A. Linick, the department’s inspector general, to shield himself from Mr. Linick’s inquiries.
item.dc:creator: Edward Wong
item.category: House Committee on Oversight and Government Reform
item.media:credit: Pool photo by Nicholas Kamm
item.media:description: Secretary of State Mike Pompeo urged the ouster of Steve A. Linick, who was the State Department inspector general.

item.title: Testing Is Key to Beating Coronavirus, Right? Japan Has Other Ideas
item.description: The country has reported fewer deaths than other major nations and ended a state of emergency even while maintaining a low testing rate.
item.dc:creator: Ben Dooley and Makiko Inoue
item.media:credit: Philip Fong/Agence France-Presse — Getty Images
item.media:description: A demonstration in Tokyo of a swab test for the coronavirus.

item.title: Russians Are Angry, but Putin’s Foes Struggle to Seize the Moment
item.description: The main opposition leader, Aleksei A. Navalny, has seen his YouTube audience triple during the coronavirus crisis. But street protest, his most potent weapon, is off the table.
item.dc:creator: Anton Troianovski
item.media:credit: Sergey Ponomarev for The New York Times
item.media:description: In Moscow last month. As Russia fights the coronavirus, the authorities have moved against even one-person public protests.
